posts.name: A-Pou's Taste
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘A-Pou’s Taste is a small  Taiwanese cafe that has the feel of a well-worn neighborhood spot. It  opened in 2017 serving top-notch dumplings — pork and pumpkin are best —  in the afternoon and fan tuan and egg sandwiches in the morning.’ From the Eater YouTube description about A-Pou’s Taste, “Meet the woman behind A-Pou’s Taste, the famous Taiwanese pot sticker food truck and restaurant in NYC. Yeh Chi Yao named her business after the Taiwanese word “a pou,” meaning “old lady,” sharing her belief that more life experience makes for better, tastier food. Since introducing Taiwanese  street food to the scene 15 years ago, A-Pou’s Taste hasn’t slowed down,  producing over 1,000 pot stickers every day.’

posts.name: Allswell
posts.note: Allswell is a seasonally-driven, rustic American pub located in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They work closely with farmers and purveyors to source fresh, interesting ingredients for their guests. Allswell's approach is casual, and their menu changes frequently to keep fresh energy flowing throughout the seasons. From their website, 'ALLSWELL is a seasonally-driven, rustic American pub located in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. We work closely with farmers and purveyors to source fresh, interesting ingredients for our guests. Allswell's approach is casual, and our menu changes frequently in order to keep fresh energy flowing throughout the seasons.'

posts.name: Ba Xuyen
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘This no-frills Vietnamese sandwichery in Sunset Park delivers examples of banh mi in fine form with several variations, but no unnecessarily fussy spins. Get one with pate and cold cuts, grilled pork, sardines, or saucy meatballs. The pale green, creamy avocado shake is a favorite accompaniment. The second oldest of the city’s dedicated Vietnamese sandwich shops is a contender for best banh mi in town. Steps from Sunset Park, the shop offers a menu of sandwiches and Vietnamese snacks. There are 11 kinds of banh mi, and our favorites are the banh mi pate thit nguoi, with six layered meats, or banh mi ca moi, featuring canned sardines in a vinegary chile sauce. This classic Vietnamese sandwich shop on the northern verge of Sunset Park’s Chinatown is nearly as old as Banh Mi Saigon, and it constitutes a local hangout for the Vietnamese population, who sit drinking tea and feasting on snacks from the cases that line the walls. The hilltop park from which the neighborhood gets its name is nearby, so why not carry out and have a picnic?’ Martinez and Mu recommend ordering the #1 Roast Pork Bahn Mi.

posts.name: Bagel Hole
posts.note: Bagel Hole is a snug, no-nonsense outpost specializing in hand-rolled, crusty bagels, plus hearty sandwiches. From their website, 'Bagel Hole offers hand-rolled, old-style bagels. All of our bagels are made and baked on the premise. We use only the finest all-natural ingredients in all our bagels. No additives or preservatives. Then we bake them to a crisp golden brown. Oh, and by the way, our bagels are boiled and never steamed like those other so-called bagels... (rolls with holes). We were established in 1985 and brought with us over ten years of experience at the time. We were taught the art of the hand-rolled bagel by a gentleman who had been making bagels since he was a young man back in Germany during the 1940s. His experience was not only in bagels and bialys but a broad range of breads and pastries.'

posts.name: Balthazar
posts.note: Balthazar is an iconic French brasserie with steak frites, brunch, and pastries in a classy space with red banquettes. Delaney and Claire from Bon Appetit (YouTube) recommend ordering the full English breakfast, the Eggs Florentine with artichokes, and the tartine with bread and jam. Delaney and Christina Chaey also recommend getting the bread/rolls. From the New York City Eater website, 'Keith McNally’s enduring Soho brasserie is one of the most spectacular places to enjoy brunch in New York City. It actually might be the greatest brunch restaurant in the world, for that matter. Balthazar is a swell place to go with a small group for a celebratory meal on the weekends. For a real splurge, order a seafood tower, steak tartare, and Champagne.'
posts.rcmmnd: Delaney and Claire from Bon Appetit (YouTube)

posts.name: Brancaccio's Food Shop
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Dyker Heights-born and Staten Island-raised Joe Brancaccio opened his namesake Brancaccio’s sandwich shop in 2010. A decade and a half later, the takeout-only shop feels just as special, serving up Italian American sandwiches with a decidedly New York point of view. In particular, he’s set himself apart with a lengthy list of egg sandwiches (like one with guanciale and pickled onions). But there are other options like a chicken cutlet with prosciutto, artichoke, and fontina cheese with herb hot sauce or a meatball sub with pine nuts and raisins.’ Martinez and Mu recommend ordering the meatball sub.

posts.name: Bunna Cafe
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Bunna Cafe was started by Sam Saverance and Liyuw Ayalew as a pop-up to highlight the importance of coffee (bunna) in Ethiopian cuisine and culture through elaborate coffee ceremonies. It has since become a permanent fixture of the vegan food scene in the neighborhood. Perfect for sharing, the main attraction is the beyaynetu, a feast of injera and stewed side dishes that can be eaten solo or portioned for larger groups. Despite all the changes in the neighborhood, Bunna Cafe remains a Bushwick staple. Sample the family-style platters of split pea-based shiro or the red lentil misir wot, served with spongy injera bread that’s perfect for sharing. A semi-secret gem of the neighborhood, the meat-free Bunna Cafe is paradise for vegetarians and vegans looking for exciting dining options. But it also won’t scare away even the most ardent of carnivores. Aromatic stews like shiro (split peas simmered with tomato, spices, garlic, ginger, and onion) and the spicier, red lentil-based misir wot are refreshing, healthy, and most importantly, tasty. The warm lighting and live steel drum music are perfect for lingering with friends, so order one of the feasts for groups, to be scooped up with spongy, slightly sour injera bread. Save room for baklava and original cocktails like the “CuCumba!” (gin, celery and grapefruit shrub, and muddled cucumber).’

posts.name: Caputo's Bake Shop
posts.note: Caputo's Bake Shop is a bustling, iconic Italian bakery known for its wide variety of breads, cookies, and baked goods. From their website, 'Have you ever experienced traditional Italian baking? There's nothing quite like the mouthwatering taste and heavenly smell. Instead of settling for average bakeries, stop by Caputo's Pastry Shoppe. We're a local pastry shop in Long Branch, NJ, that maintains family traditions. Our bakery has been open since 1923 and family-run for five generations. We guarantee you won't be disappointed by our aromatic coffee and delicious baked goods. Visit us today to find out what makes us one of the premier bakeries in the area. Have you ever experienced traditional Italian baking? There's nothing quite like the mouthwatering taste and heavenly smell. Instead of settling for average bakeries, stop by Caputo's Pastry Shoppe. We're a local pastry shop in Long Branch, NJ, that maintains family traditions. Our bakery has been open since 1923 and family-run for five generations. We guarantee you won't be disappointed by our aromatic coffee and delicious baked goods. Visit us today to find out what makes us one of the premier bakeries in the area. We make all our bread and pastries from scratch. We adhere to traditional baking styles. Our showcase features specialty cakes that are ready to go. Come enjoy your morning coffee along with a Danish pastry. Or visit later in the day to pick up a cake for a special event. Whatever you're looking for, our friendly staff is here to help.' The Burger Show recommends ordering the burger.

posts.name: Carmenta’s
posts.note: From their website, ‘Specializing in Italian-American classics, Chef Dom was inspired to open Carmenta’s due to the lack of authentic, delicious, and no-frills Italian food in the neighborhood. Dom’s parents immigrated to New York from Naples, Italy and settled down roots in Queens, New York, where he was born and raised. His earliest memories are being in the kitchen with his mom, where he developed a love and passion for cooking. Sunday Supper was the highlight of the week in his household, with his mom making Mafalda with meat sauce, which was the very first menu item on the Carmenta’s menu in 2018. From meatballs to arancini, everything on the menu has been inspired by growing up as an Italian American in New York. Stop in for house-made pasta, homemade mozzarella, and sandwiches. Eat-in or take anything to go.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘This resolutely Italian-American place concentrates on red sauced specialties in a largely familiar vein, representing a rather spectacular species of comfort food. Our favorites include mafalde (a ribbon pasta with wavy edges) with beef bolognese, and the meatball parm hero, available in medium and large sizes. Smaller snacks like rice balls, garlic bread, and Caesar salad are also available.’ Martinez and Mu recommend ordering the Jose Special, which has meatballs, fried eggplant, homemade mozzarella, salsa verde, and Pecorino DOP.

posts.name: Court Street Grocers
posts.note: Court Street Grocers is a specialty market that offers grocery items, gourmet sandwiches, prepared foods, and quality meats. Delaney and Christina Chaey from Bon Appetit (YouTube) recommend the following as their best sandwiches were the Ali, the Delite, and the smoked Salomon. From the Serious Eats NYC website, 'Court Street Grocers is making some of the best sandwiches we've had recently (and we are sandwich crazies)—plus you can wash them down with tough-to-find-in-NYC regional sodas. Like Cheerwine, for which they drive down to North Carolina to pick up crates of the real cane-sugar version. The fridge also stocks cans of Vernors ginger ale, glass bottles of Bubble Up, and Kombucha.'
posts.rcmmnd: Delaney and Christina Chaey from Bon Appetit (YouTube)

posts.name: Cuts and Slices
posts.note: Cool eatery selling pies and slices with creative toppings like chicken-and-waffle, oxtail, and curry shrimp. From their website, 'More than just pizza: A slice of community. At Cuts and Slices, we're all about bringing people together over great pizza. We aim to create a cozy, safe space that feels like home for everyone. Our mission goes beyond making delicious food; we're here to support our team and give back to the community. With innovative recipes and heartfelt connections, we're more than just a pizza place—we're a slice of life. With creative and unconventional pizza toppings like oxtail, Shrimp, and Lobster Black truffle Alfredo, we continuously push the boundaries of traditional pizza-making. Cuts and Slices: Every Slice Feels Like Home. We're not just making great pizza; we're creating a place where you belong. Join us in a cozy, welcoming space where every bite supports a vision of togetherness and fresh ideas.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Defonte's Sandwich Shop
posts.note: From a fan website, ‘Defonte’s Sandwich Shop, a legendary establishment located at 379 Columbia Street in the Red Hook neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York City, has been delighting locals and visitors with its iconic deli sandwiches for well over a century. This historic gem is not just a place to grab a sandwich; it’s a cornerstone of the Italian-American culinary experience and a testament to the enduring legacy of traditional, mouthwatering deli fare. Since its inception in 1922, Defonte’s has been a cherished culinary destination, originally catering to the Italian longshoremen who frequented the Brooklyn waterfront. When you step into Defonte’s Sandwich Shop, located in the historic neighborhood of Red Hook, Brooklyn, you’re in for a treat. As a local establishment with a rich culinary history, Defonte’s has a menu that’s packed with a variety of mouthwatering options that will satisfy every sandwich craving. One of the standout features of Defonte’s is the Staten Island influence on the menu. The Red Hook menu is a testament to the commitment to providing the finest deli-style sandwiches, which have kept customers coming back for over a century.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘Since 1922, this portside Italian sandwich shop has served heaping portions of cured pork on rolls to workers and passersby in Red Hook. The signature sub is the colossal Nicky Special, layered with a trio of ham, salami, and capocollo, plus fried slices of eggplant, provolone, and hot peppers mixed with oregano and pickled vegetables. Everyone has their favorite sandwich here, so the “best” order is divisive.’

posts.name: Dekalb Market Hall
posts.note: Dekalb Market Hall is a bustling destination that houses 40 food vendors, including old-school and new-school New York City restaurants. From the New York Times website, 'DeKalb Market Hall is among the city’s largest food halls. Brightened by neon signage, it is home to more than 40 entrepreneurs selling everything from pickles to pho in about 60,000 square feet of underground space in Downtown Brooklyn.' From the Lonely Planet website, 'Choose from hand-made pierogi and beer, churros, crepes, arepas (cornbread sandwiches), French patisserie, tacos, brimming bagels and plenty more.'

posts.name: Di Fara Pizza
posts.note: Di Fara Pizza serves pizza fans that trek to this no-frills Midwood storefront and queue up to partake of its storied slices. From their website 'Domenico De Marco, or “Dom,” opened Di Fara Pizza in 1965 after emigrating to Brooklyn from the Province of Caserta in Italy. Before Di Fara Pizza, Dom spent time working on a Huntington farm until someone told him about a “good spot” on Avenue J in Brooklyn. That “good spot” is now known as the best pizzeria in New York City. Each pie of pizza is handcrafted by the master himself, Dom, who spent over 53 years perfecting his pizza. With several of his children supporting him in the kitchen, this legend still cooks at the age of 82. Many of the ingredients are imported from Italy and forms a taste that can't be replicated. In his piping hot retro oven, Dom has each mouthwatering pie ready to be devoured in just minutes. Today, both the Midwood and Williamsburg locations continue to be family-owned and operated.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Emily
posts.note: Emily is a cozy, gourmet eatery that serves wood-fired Neapolitan pizzas, rustic small plates, along with different types of pasta. Pro Home Cook recommends the Emily white pizza, named after the owner, containing mozzarella, pistachio, truffle sottocenere, and honey. From the NewYork City Eater website, ‘This Clinton Hill restaurant has spawned a second location in the West Village and a small chain of pizzerias operating under the name Emmy Squared. None make a burger quite like here. The legendary Emmy Burger, a thick patty topped with aged cheddar and caramelized onion on a pretzel bun, is easily one of the best in the city. We should mention that it costs more than $30, which thankfully includes fries, but it won’t disappoint on a special occasion.’

posts.name: F and F Pizzeria
posts.note: F and F Pizzeria uses choice ingredients and techniques to distinguish this pizza created in collaboration with baking pros. From their website, ‘Located in a converted garage between Franks wine bar and Frankies 457 Spuntino, F and F serves pizza developed in collaboration with legendary bakers Chris Bianco and Chad Robertson: a classic New York slice using the best ingredients and timeless techniques.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘The tomato pie at F&F showcases why the pizzeria makes the ultimate New York slice: it’s all in the sauce and the dough. The former is a touch fruity and amply acidic, thanks to canned tomatoes, while the latter produces a flavorful crust with a delicately crisp bottom and a touch of gooeyness in the outer rim.’ Pro Home Cook’s the Partanna white pizza with mozzarella, red onion, Calabrian chili, orange blossom, and honey.

posts.name: Fan Fan Doughnuts
posts.note: From their website, ‘At Fan-Fan are dedicated to making great doughnuts, making people happy, and bringing people together. We want to celebrate diversity and are inspired by the flavors and traditions from around the globe. We take a lot of care and pride in what we do. We make our doughnuts in small batches throughout the day, so you will always have the freshest and often warm one! We try to get the best ingredients we can, and there is so much thought, love, and care into every detail. At the end of the day, we strive to create a loving community and bring joy to the world. We look forward to welcoming you soon.’ From the Eater website, ‘At one of NYC’s most popular bakeries, Fan Fan, there are certain pastries that people will specifically seek out. One such pastry is the Danny Boy doughnut or a brown butter salted caramel doughnut.’ Joshua recommends ordering the hot chocolate, and the doughnuts are great, too.

posts.name: Farrell's Bar and Grill
posts.note: From the New York Magazine website, ‘Farrell’s is the real McCoy, dating back to 1933 when Park Slope was Irish and Irish meant tough. They’ve finally added stools, but there’s still no table service, so belly up to the long bar and shout your order. Ordering a large beer — i.e., Budweiser — will get you a 32-ounce Styrofoam bucket. A few members of the fairer sex do show up: Shirley MacLaine caused quite a neighborhood scandal when she insisted on being the first unchaperoned woman to be served here in the early ‘70s.’

posts.name: Fei Long Market
posts.note: Fei Long Market is a large store stocking Chinese grocery items, housewares, and more, along with a food court offering hot Asian dishes. New York City Eater website recently mentioned, 'This anchoring stall in the Fei Long Market’s food court, wonderfully close to the Eighth Avenue N stop in Sunset Park’s Chinatown, has what might be the best soup dumplings in town. These are the no-frills article, available in six variations, some surprising, including one filled with pork and crab roe, and another featuring vegetables and mushrooms. Six to an order, the dumplings are bigger than usual and exceedingly thin-skinned, packing an improbable quantity of soup. Cash only.' From an older Serious Eats website article (prices may have gone up) they mentioned the following places in the food court that is attached to the market: Shall We Eat, Inc. has a window display of spit-roasted meats, or Two Meats Over Rice for ($4.75), Shanghai Dumpling House, where you can watch as cooks stuff and meticulously pleat hand-rolled rounds of dough with various fillings or the thin noodle of the Pork Xiao Long Bao ($3.75 for 6) or the LaoMa MaLaTang or maybe the Grand Noodle House for the hand-pulled noodles.

posts.name: Fette Sau
posts.note: Fette Sau is a popular dry-rub BBQ, beer, and bourbon purveyor with an industrial cafeteria-style decor, and wall mural. From their website, 'In the early spring of 2007, Joe Carroll opened Fette Sau, a barbeque restaurant with a bar focused on local craft beer and small production American spirits. The menu is simple and focused on the meats, all of which are heritage breeds raised naturally by small family farms and contain no antibiotics or hormones. The barbeque is one part Central Texas and one part New York Deli. The meat is ordered by weight and served on butcher paper. All the traditional barbeque cuts are served along with plenty of not-so-traditional things like beef tongue pastrami, pork belly, and veal heart.'

posts.name: Fini Pizza
posts.note: From their website, ‘Fini Pizza is made in Brooklyn. Inspired by a lifelong obsession of neighborhood pizzerias, we want our expression of the iconic NYC slice shop to create memorable dining experiences for all guests by honoring the past, embracing the present, and investing in the future of our community. Our distinct green trash cans are purchased, placed in front of small businesses, and maintained daily by  Fini in an effort to keep our neighborhood and City cleaner. To date,  Fini has purchased 30 cans for Williamsburg and Downtown Brooklyn.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘Okay, so Fini is a neighborhood slice joint with lawn chairs out front (bring your uncle’s tank top), almond ices in the freezer, and a website that greets you with a slick video of a staffer in noise-canceling headphones walking the streets of Brooklyn in shiny custom swag. It’s a chill place to spend $25 on two  Neapolitan-style cheese slices and an IPA.’

posts.name: Foster Sundry
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Foster Sundry is a Bushwick butcher shop that sells cardamom buns and $20 bouquets of flowers: It’s also the unlikely setting of the area’s best breakfast burrito. Packed inside a griddled flour tortilla, there’s scrambled egg, Oaxaca cheese, burnt hash brown, and lots of Frank’s hot sauce. They come with mushrooms or red chorizo. Bushwick’s favorite breakfast burrito comes from a corner store that sells cardamom buns and bouquets of flowers. The secret is Oaxaca cheese, Frank’s hot sauce, and crumbly sausage.’ Andrew Rae (Babish) recommends ordering the breakfast burrito.

posts.name: Frankel's Delicatessen and Appetizing
posts.note: Frankel's Delicatessen and Appetizing is a contemporary Jewish deli specializing in bagels with smoked fish, along with classic sandwiches, and brisket. Delaney and Molly Baz's favorite dishes they ordered were the hot pastrami ruben, the whitefish club, and the AM Spec. From their website, 'Frankel's is a family-owned and operated New York-style deli bringing Jewish fare to the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York. Raised on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the brothers behind the eponymous delicatessen are Zach and Alex Frankel. The brothers have translated their rich memories and experiences as life-long New Yorkers into a restaurant with timeless appeal. Combining both appetizing and deli, Frankel's specializes in small batch cooking, offering a curated selection of smoked fish, smoked and braised meat, and fresh salads.'
posts.rcmmnd: Delaney and Molly Baz from Bon Appettit (YouTube)

posts.name: Frankies 457 Spuntino
posts.note: Frankies 457 Spuntino is a popular neighborhood Italian with Tuscan cooking served in a tiled room or out in the ample garden. Alex, the French Guy Cooking from YouTube, recommends the meatballs and red sauce. From Serious Eats website, 'When eating at Frank Falcinelli and Frank Castronovo's Frankies Spuntino, not ordering the meatballs is really a crime. They are by far the best meatballs I've ever had in a restaurant, and possibly my life.'
posts.rcmmnd: Alex the French Guy Cooking from YouTube

posts.name: Golden Diner
posts.note: From their website, ‘We’re an Asian Diner located underneath the Manhattan Bridge in Chinatown NY. We specialize in serving classic NY diner dishes that have been influenced by the neighborhood. Come on by and hang out. We’d love to cook up some tasty food for you.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘The egg sandwich at Golden Diner is a studied affair, with soft scrambled eggs that spill off the edges of a sweet Chinese scallion milk bun. The eggs share space with processed cheese, smoky bacon, and a hamburger-sized potato cake that’s crunchy on the outside and silky on the inside. Golden Diner serves breakfast until 10 p.m., so the Chinatown egg and cheese sando on a scallion milk bun and the honey butter pancakes are available all day. Dinner ushers in the Golden cheeseburger with gochujang sauce, Korean wings, and a chile crisp wedge salad.’ Andrew Rae (Babish) recommends ordering the breakfast burrito.

posts.name: Giovanni's Brooklyn Eats
posts.note: Giovanni's Brooklyn Eats serves seasonal menus of classic Italian eats and is the star at this warm, cozy restaurant with outside seating. From their website, 'Real Italian dishes made from real Italian family recipes, prepared and served in a restaurant created and ran by an owner raised in a real Brooklyn Italian household. That’s what you experience when you eat at Giovanni’s.'
posts.rcmmnd: David Chang's Netflix show Ugly Delicious

posts.name: Greene Grape Provisions
posts.note: Greene Grape Provisions is a gourmet market offering a butcher, coffee bar, cheesemonger, wine store, and bakery that does their own whole animal butchery. From their website, 'The Greene Grape' is three unique businesses with one shared mission – to provide goods and services made with integrity, skill, and pride. Our three locations on Fulton Street provide high quality and natural food and beverages to the community. We believe in supporting small-batch and local producers as well as products that are both ethically produced with a mindfulness for sustainability. Above all, we believe that this is a tasty way to live, which is why our motto is: Food and Wine You Will Enjoy! The Greene Grape Annex is a neighborhood café and bar that provides a gathering place for the Fort Greene community. We offer everything from your morning coffee to an evening beer. The annex offers a great menu of food and wine as well as cocktails!'

posts.name: Hometown Bar-B-Que
posts.note: Hometown Bar-B-Que is a rustic counter-service choice featuring slow-smoked meats, craft beer, and live music on weekends. Delaney and Brad from Bon Appetit (YouTube) recommend the spare rib, the shredded lamb breast, and the smoke turkey. Other's suggest you order the Korean sticky ribs along with the lamb belly and some pickled red onions. From the New York City Eater website, 'Hometown is pitmaster Billy Durney's vision of NYC barbecue. While it leans toward Texas-style barbecue, it is at its heart and soul a New York restaurant. It was previously declared the best barbecue in the city by Eater critic Ryan Sutton, and many barbecue aficionados agree. The move here is to order everything on the menu — but especially the short rib, brisket, Jamaican jerk ribs, and spare ribs.'
posts.rcmmnd: Delaney and Brad from Bon Appetit (YouTube)

posts.name: Hot Bread Kitchen
posts.note: Hot Bread Kitchen is a retail stall inside La Marqueta marketplace with global breads and coffee along with breakfast and lunch fare. From their website, 'Hot Bread Kitchen’s mission is to create economic opportunity through careers in food. We believe in a food system that equitably compensates talent and sustains a diverse workforce while celebrating culinary tradition and innovation. Our work helps women, immigrants, and people of color thrive as workers and entrepreneurs within the food system and is helping to make the system itself more conscious and equitable for all.' From New York City Eater website, 'Hot Bread Kitchen has a local food business incubator program. But the nonprofit also has a training arm, with graduates placed in jobs at restaurants like Breads Bakery, Russ & Daughters, and Roberta’s. It’s also known for its wholesale bakery, which supplies bread to grocery stores and restaurants across the city like Whole Foods and chef Daniel Boulud’s Boulud Sud on the Upper West Side, and it recently opened a stall at Chelsea Market that features products from its incubator members.

posts.name: Impasto
posts.note: From the Gothamist website, 'Impasto Pizza Is Slinging Superb Square  Slices In Clinton Hill. Will it be 'third time's a charm' here in Clinton Hill? For most of the past decade, this tiny Brooklyn slice joint on Waverly Avenue was home to the utilitarian, mostly unloved  Mario's Pizza. The crew from nearby Aita, a popular rustic Italian restaurant, took over in 2017, serving both Calabrese-style and classic NYC round pies, but a terrible fire' all but destroyed the place two years later (thankfully, no one was hurt). Then, last summer, team Aita decided to try again, this time with Roman-ish square slices and pies, and the shop was reborn as Impasto Pizza al Taglio. The pizza at Impasto is excellent, with an airy, delightfully chewy crust that you might associate with the high-hydration pies of Rome or, here in NYC, at places like PQR or the late Mani In Pasta. But as co-owner Luca Pelliccioni explained to me, it's not strictly Roman-style because of the sheer weight of toppings he piles on. They're totally delicious, however, and given the steady stream of happy customers popping inside or, more often, ordering from the sidewalk window last weekend, the locals have definitely taken notice. I loved the baseline Margherita, loaded with gooey mozzarella and a tomato sauce that nailed that proper sweet-acid balance. Add a mess of meat on top in the form of slightly spicy, wonderfully greasy Pepperoni cups, and you've got a top-tier contender for the best slice of this sort in town. The Roman classic Patate e Rosmarino slice was beautifully done: the potatoes cut super thin and charred to crisp, the rosemary sprigs sprinkled with a heavy hand, and lots of flaky sea salt adding even more life to the party. But my favorite slice of the afternoon feast was probably the Salsiccia e  Funghi, a rich, earthy concoction of sausage crumbles, fat chunks of mushroom, and baked-on cheese.'

posts.name: Irie Jerk Chicken
posts.note: From their website, 'Our passion for authentic Caribbean cuisine. Irie Jerk Chicken is not just a restaurant; it's a culinary journey through the vibrant flavors of the Caribbean. Our recipes have been perfected over time to bring you the most mouthwatering jerk chicken and more. Every bite is a taste of the Jamaican sunshine, and we can't wait to share it with you. Our story begins with a passion for bringing the authentic taste of jerk chicken and more to the bustling streets of New York. We take pride in our heritage and the rich culinary traditions that inspire our menu. With a commitment to quality and taste, we invite you to savor the essence of the Caribbean. Come join us for a culinary adventure that will tantalize your taste buds and leave you craving for more.'

posts.name: Kotti Berliner Döner Kebab
posts.note: From the Kotti Berliner Döner Kebab website, 'Kotti Berliner Döner’s founder, Erkan Emre, has been eating döner since his childhood in Berlin. But when he moved to New York City, he noticed there was nowhere to feed his craving for Berliner Döner Kebab. The only solution was to bring döner to New York City himself, so he partnered with his Co-Founder, food industry expert Michael Stark, to turn his vision into reality. Kotti was then chosen from hundreds of applicants to participate in Smorgasburg, Brooklyn’s premiere outdoor food festival.'

posts.name: L'Industrie Pizzeria
posts.note: From their website,’ Superior service, personalized attention. From the City of Pistoia and the streets of NYC. We’ve come together to bring you L’industrie Pizzeria. With the artful techniques and passions of Italy blended with the flavors and characteristics of a classic New York slice. We work daily to bridge the gap between these worlds while putting quality and passion above all.’ From the New York City Eater website,’ Opened in 2017, L’Industrie was once one of Brooklyn’s best-kept secrets: a top-tier slice shop where it was possible to pop in for a pie or a cup of gelato with olive oil and salt. Now, it’s wildly popular both in Brooklyn and Manhattan, often with lines down the block. Slices come out on greasy paper plates with crisp, naturally leavened crusts and ample toppings like burrata and pepperoni. Good to know: Check out the lunchtime sandwich specials like capocollo, provolone, and a spicy pepper mix. And don’t skip sweets like gelato, sorbets, and a maritozzo. One of the great pleasures of modern Williamsburg is dropping into L’Industrie Pizzeria and ordering one of the paper-thin Romanesque slices. The burrata slice — the one they’re most known for — shows off a lovely contrast between cool, milky dairy and the warm tomato sauce. Over the years, they’ve expanded their storefront on the block to meet the immense demand. That included an outpost in the West Village last year.’

posts.name: Las Americas Meat Market
posts.note: From the New York Times website 'Las Americas, a carnicería in Sunnyside, Queens, has been serving the meat needs of the Colombian, and greater Latino, communities for nearly 30 years. Las Americas serves an almost impossibly inexpensive menu of trencherman’s fare, prepared with a surprisingly light hand. Unlike plenty of other Colombian kitchens in the city, the cooks at Las Americas don’t hide behind fat and salt.'

posts.name: The Long Island Bar
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘The Long Island Bar and Restaurant has been open since 1951 when its clientele consisted of hungry dockworkers looking for somewhere to eat. It closed in 2007 and was revived a few years later by its current owners, Toby Cecchini and Joel Tompkins. They kept the old neon sign, refurbished the space, and added a menu of cocktails that are reasonably priced for the area. There’s table service and a full food menu with cheese curds and a standout burger. Opened in 1951, the Long Island Bar holds court on a prominent corner in Cobble Hill. The bar is now run by Joel Tompkins and Toby Cecchini. (The latter bartender is credited with creating the Cosmopolitan.) It remains a great place to drink, with reasonably priced cocktails, like martinis and gimlets, that don’t need theatrics to impress. The cheeseburger and cheese curds are among the reasons the Long Island Bar has remained popular, straddling bar and restaurant with ease.’ Insider Food recommends ordering the cheeseburger.

posts.name: Lowerline
posts.note: From their website, ‘We are a classic New Orleans-inspired neighborhood restaurant nestled in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. We’re here to pay homage to the joints that make New Orleans the best food city in America. The places where you can delight in freshly shucked oysters on the half shell without pretense, feel happy with a hot roast beef po-boy dripping with gravy, enjoy a steaming bowl of seafood gumbo, and wash it all back with an ice-cold beer. Our food is pure Creole soul made fresh daily from scratch. And we’re nice. Come hang out.’ From the NewYork City Eater website, ‘Lowerline in Prospect Heights is one of the city’s most faithful renditions of a New Orleans dive, where one might dash in for a po’boy that reproduces the sandwich perfectly with the roll and a thick mayo, or linger for a bowl of crawfish etouffee, or a plate of ham, rice, and red beans. The fried oyster po’boy is a thing of beauty, a memorable meal in itself. Lowerline in Prospect Heights is a worthwhile go-to for any Gulf Coast transplant seeking out the culinary classics that define the New Orleans restaurant scene. Chef and owner John Verlander, a Louisiana native, opened the Cajun-inspired spot to bring a taste of the Gulf with a collection of regional classics. The menu features several po’ boy classics, including the fried catfish and fried shrimp varieties of the sandwich. While you’re there, be sure to try out the crawfish etouffee or gumbo.’

posts.name: Lucali
posts.note: From their website, ‘Accidental Pizzaiolo Mark Iacono opened Lucali as a labor of love, to save the local candy store of his Carroll Gardens youth from an uncertain fate.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘Mark Iacono’s thin-crust pizzas, made with a three-cheese blend of fresh and imported mozzarella and Grana Padano, plus fresh basil, consistently draw long lines, and it’s impossible to make a reservation. The move is to show up before 5 p.m., add your name to the list, and grab a drink in the neighborhood while you wait. Cash only, BYOB. Lucali starts taking names for dinner at 5 p.m., but fifteen minutes earlier, there’s usually a line down the block. Then there are the rules: It’s cash only. You have a time limit on your table. It’s B.Y.O. wine, but only one bottle is allowed. New Yorkers put up with this because pizza at Lucali is quite special. The dough is thin and chewy, with blistered spots around the perimeter. The only other item on the menu is a calzone. You’ll want to order it. More than a decade in, Lucali still pulls in long lines for its fine pizza and calzones in a wonderfully cozy space. It’s a restaurant that believes in a few frills, where servers greet tables with ease and a wine key, and the menu boasts no more than five options. Bring wine and arrive before 5 p.m. for a chance at snagging a table. Note that, at least at one point, the restaurant only allowed one bottle of wine per five people to speed things along.’

posts.name: Luigi's Pizza
posts.note: Neighborhood spot since 1973, serving up NYC-style pizza and slices in compact, no-frills surroundings. From their website. ‘It’s 1973. Having just arrived from Italy, Luigi is sitting behind the table with his family. He knows he needs to act now. After all, for years, he has been pursuing his family’s passion. He exclaims: “Best Pizza in New York! There shall be no compromise on finest, natural ingredients. We shall grow them in our own backyard if we have to!” From day one and now, 37 years later, Luigi’s passion lives on in a cozy restaurant in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Finest olive oil, specially picked ripe tomatoes, peppers, and our sauce make our pizza simply delicious! Come on in and try it! You won’t ever eat another pizza anywhere else.’

posts.name: The Meat Hook
posts.note: The Meat Hook is a cool butcher shop offering beef, pork, lamb, and poultry products sourced from local farms. From their website, 'The mission of The Meat Hook is to bring top quality, local, pasture-raised meats to a community in an unpretentious, fun environment. We believe in supporting our mission by paying our farmers a sustainable price for their practices and quality and carrying on that accessibility to our customers. We invest in farms that practice regenerative agriculture. That means agriculture that focuses on soil health through raising and rotating pastures for 100% grass-finished beef, fully pastured heritage pigs, lamb, and poultry. We started the business because we believed that the transaction of buying meat should be simple and transparent. We wanted to buy whole animals from local farms, butcher them in house, make delicious products and tell customers about it.'

posts.name: Mile End Delicatessen
posts.note: Mile End Delicatessen is a small spot drawing big crowds for smoked meat sandwiches and other Montreal-style Jewish deli staples. From their website, 'Using our grandmothers’ time-honored recipes as the foundation for our menu, we updated traditional dishes and focused on fresh ingredients and from-scratch cooking techniques. The restaurant is a combination of a Jewish delicatessen and a Canadian-style restaurant, modeled after delis found in Montreal’s famous Mile End neighborhood. This specific style of deli inspired us to offer signature smoked meats and sandwiches, homemade hotdogs with tangy kraut, poutine, fresh whitefish salad, and more.'

posts.name: Mission Sandwich Social
posts.note: It is a simple eatery with an industrial vibe and is fixing up generous subs, including vegetarian and vegan options. From their website, ‘I’m on a mission… to bring big, saucy subs to the heart of Williamsburg Brooklyn. Inspired by my love of  sandwiches, baking, fine cuisine & heavy metal, Mission Sandwich  Social brings together many of my passions—and the best Dutch Crunch  bread this side of the Golden Gate Bridge.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘Mission Sandwich Social is a new Williamsburg spot by chef  Brian Tsao, an alum of Beauty and Essex, where sandwiches are prepared on Dutch crunch, a flakey bread with an apparently strong fan base in  San Francisco. I had never heard of Dutch crunch, and I was curious why more New York spots hadn’t yet tried their hands at it, so I stopped by for the Peking Turkey version (turkey and cheddar with bean sprouts,  pickled carrots, and scallion, doused in mayo, sriracha, and hoisin). Sandwiches here come in luxe, purse-like to-go containers, accompanied by a surprise Tootsie Pop. Overall, the Peking Turkey is a banger, but there may actually be a thing as a sandwich too big. A word of advice:  Saving the other half of this $17 lunch isn’t ideal because the  decadent sauces make the sandwich get soggy the next day, so make sure  to come really hungry or bring a buddy.’

posts.name: Nenes Taqueria
posts.note: From their website, ‘Authenticity doesn’t get any better! Handmade corn tortillas and top-notch plates using the freshest ingredients. Passionately serving our clients with our family recipes which have been passed down from generations!’ From the New York Eater website, ‘A couple of years ago, this place was called Eric’s Mini Market, and Nene’s was a small counter on one side. Now it’s a hopping place, with red-stenciled signs and a rollicking crew. Both the Al Pastor and the chorizo tacos ($3.90 each) are top-notch. The tortillas are the coarse, yellow cornmeal kind, made on the spot, very LA. Former Jean-Georges cook Andrés Tonatiuh Galindo Maria opened Nene’s Deli Taqueria in honor of his family in Puebla. He serves up Mexican classics like a pork mulita alongside Los Angeles inventions like Birria ramen. The birria, a meat stew made with guajillo chile and garlic, comes topped with onion, cheese, and cilantro and is served on homemade tortillas. These juicy tacos have quickly become the talk of the neighborhood and have inspired a legion of local imitators.’ NOTE: - They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Peep’s Kitchen
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Peep’s Kitchen is one of Greenpoint’s best-kept secrets. The small, family-run shop specializes in Korean fried chicken. The gangjeong preparation, pictured here, is stir-fried in a sticky, sweet sauce, then topped with sesame seeds and sliced almonds, but the padak is also good: It comes without sauce and has shaved scallions on top. The small restaurant does not have indoor seating, but it’s a great takeout option in the area and serves its food on most delivery apps. Stop by Peeps Kitchen for some serious fried and glazed chicken, with wings that come with sweet and spicy soy garlic or “extreme” sauces. It’s easy to pick out the restaurant from its blue mural depicting chicks grazing in chef’s hats along McGuiness Boulevard. There’s no seating, but the restaurant is located a short distance from McCarren Park and delivers on most ordering platforms. Korean fried chicken, done well, should still have some crunch to it after a few minutes in a takeout box — and the containers of boneless fried bird at Peeps never disappoint. This Greenpoint restaurant has no indoor seating, so count on a well-oiled takeout and delivery operation slinging orders of fried wings and glazed gangjeong chicken. Place orders for pickup online or over the phone to avoid a wait outside the shop.’ Adam recommends ordering the Korean fried chicken.

posts.name: Pizza Secret
posts.note: From the Pizza Secret website, ‘Passion for good food runs in Rosario’s family. This tradition has been passed on from one generation to the next. It started with his grandfather, a pastry maker, followed by his father, a chef, and finally, Rosario and his eight siblings, many of whom are pizzaiolos themselves. Pizza Secret is fueled by one of the oldest wood-fired brick ovens in New York, which bakes perfect traditional and gourmet pizzas. The pizzeria offers other delicious Neapolitan nibbles, for example, crocchè, meatballs, bruschetta, and fresh pasta dishes.’ Pro Home Cook’s recommends their Cacio and Pepe white pizza with fresh mozzarella, pecorino, Buffalo ricotta, fresh ground black pepper, and basil.

posts.name: Public Display of Affection
posts.note: From the Public Display of Affection website, ‘Public Display of Affection is a wood-burning oven pizza and vegetable restaurant with a playful selection of natural wines, craft cocktails, and local draft beers. PDA opened on March 13, 2020. Located on the border of Park Slope and Gowanus in Brooklyn, New York, it is the first restaurant from Chef Rob Guimond, who brings his strong flavors and midwestern sensibilities to PDA after honing his skills at Jean Georges, Roberta’s, and Speedy Romeo. We’re here for the community and to encourage community, feeding people and nourishing connections through food.’ Pro Home Cook recommends the create your own white pizza with shiitake mushroom, garlic, three cheese of ricotta, pecorino, and mozzarella, which is cooked in a wood-fired oven with a little lemon zest as it comes out of the oven.

posts.name: R and D Foods
posts.note: R and D Foods is a small, upscale grocer offering charcuterie, cheeses, and baked goods along with prepared foods and sandwiches. Helen Rosner recommends their The Horse and Pig sandwich, which is horseradish, Benton’s bacon, butter, onions. From their website, 'We are Ilene Rosen and Sara Dima, co-owners of R&D Foods. Our store opened on May 13, 2014, but we’ve worked side by side since 2003. Our small but mighty shop is where we live and breathe every day. We’re old-school shop keepers helping our customers select cheese for the in-law's visit, wrap a present for a co-worker and pack a gift bag for the neighbors who just had a baby. We sell made-to-order sandwiches, vegetable-driven prepared foods, grocery staples, and specialties alike.'

posts.name: Radio Bakery
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Since day one, this bakery owned by the team behind Rolo’s, led by Kelly Mencin, has drawn lines (and for good reason). The online menu lists an array of croissants —vanilla citrus, maple breakfast sausage, corn cakes, cookies, and pan loaves. And if you’re looking for more of a meal, there are breakfast and lunch sandwiches and focaccia. Try not to go at prime time hours if you’re in a rush, and check their website for when certain items hit the floor. This Greenpoint bakery has drawn lines since the first day of opening in 2023. One of the reasons customers are lured is for pastries like the twice-baked pistachio croissant — even their plain, buttery version is revelatory in pastry chef Kelly Mencin’s hands. A second location of Radio Bakery is now open in Prospect Heights.’ Martinez and Mu would recommend any of their sandwiches, but were unable to get any because they had run out/were closed when they arrived. TopJaw recommends ordering the roasted mushroom or the rhubarb croissants. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Randazzo's Clam Bar
posts.note: Longtime Italian seafood joint serving raw-bar fare and red-sauce dishes in a casual waterfront venue. From the New York City Eater website, ‘Run by the fifth generation of the Randazzo family, this restaurant is not only one of the city’s best Italian restaurants, it’s one of the city’s best seafood restaurants. It dates to 1916 — an era when the bay was lined with clam shacks, and now there’s only one. Today, it serves an array of seafood classics, including both New England and Manhattan chowders, as well as a standout version of zuppa di pesce. This Sheepshead Bay establishment has been a neighborhood staple for decades, serving a variety of seafood dishes and pasta in a crowded dining room a stone’s throw from the waterfront. The restaurant is known for its red sauce, which can be ordered at varying heat levels and comes served atop various seafood dishes, including its standout fried calamari. Don’t miss the shrimp fra diavolo, as well as the raw oysters and clams.’

posts.name: Red Hook Tavern
posts.note: From their website, ‘Red Hook Tavern brings classic American tavern fare to the waterfront village in Brooklyn, where friends can share a bottle of wine, a few laughs, and a great meal. We hope from the moment you walk into this beautiful old space, it makes you feel as special as it did the first time I walked in almost five years ago. The menus pay tribute to the classic old-school taverns and legendary food establishments experienced in New York City.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘When Red Hook Tavern opened in 2019, its burgers immediately became the talk of the town. These days, it’s a lot easier to get into the restaurant, and it’s still one of the best date-night spots in South Brooklyn. Red Hook Tavern is owned by Billy Durney, of nearby Hometown, so it’s no surprise the meat reigns supreme here, though the menu has other dishes to offer, like pasta and French onion soup. Red Hook Tavern’s executive chef and general manager are also opening Cambodian restaurant Hōp, across the street this year — a part of the same hospitality group.’ TopJaw recommends ordering the cheeseburger and the spicy tomato nduja mussels.

posts.name: Roberta's
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Roberta’s is credited with putting Bushwick’s food scene on the map, and more than a decade after opening, the restaurant’s inventive wood-fired pies still hold up. Its pizzas can be eaten solo or shared for variety’s sake. Everything on the menu is great, but don’t miss the Bee Sting, a sweet and salty pie topped with soppressata, basil, and honey. There’s a sibling location in Domino Park.’ NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Santa Fe BK
posts.note: From their website, ‘We are bringing the Land Of Enchantment to the  County Of Kings, serving authentic New Mexico flavors in North  Brooklyn.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘Santa Fe BK’s homage to the Land of Enchantment highlights smothered burritos, queso, an extensive margarita list, and some off-menu surprises. Back in October of last year, when co-owners and spouses Melissa Klein and John  Watterberg opened Santa Fe BK in Williamsburg, they were only serving up three varieties of Southwestern-style breakfast burritos, french fries,  and a Green Chile burger. It was a small but mighty menu that Eater senior critic Robert Sietsema said had him “hooked” and sent him on a nostalgic trip down memory lane. Here Be Barr recommends ordering the  Green Chile Cheeseburger. The Green Chile Breakfast Burritos with either  Sausage, Bacon, or Potato looked really good, too.

posts.name: She Wolf Bakery
posts.note: From the She Wolf Bakery website, 'We started baking bread in 2009 in the wood oven at Roman’s. After dinner service, we would make a fire. Early in the morning, our baker Austin Hall would come in, rake out the coals, and bake-off bread for the day. This bread became a part of Roman’s at every service and staff meal. Soon the chefs at Marlow and Sons Diner, and Reynard wanted to bring the same quality and integrity to the bread they served. We expanded bread production to our own space in Greenpoint, and now supply the bread served at all of our restaurants and others around the city. You can purchase loaves at Marlow and Daughters and Roman's, as well at ten NYC Greenmarkets.' NOTE: They are also are at the Union Square Farmers Market in Manhattan on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

posts.name: Shelsky's Of Brooklyn Appetizing and Delicatessen
posts.note: From their website, ‘Brooklyn’s finest appetizing, smoked fish, delicatessen, and hand-rolled, kettle-boiled, homemade bagels, epic sandwiches, homemade baked sweets, and so much more... Born and bred in New York, Peter Shelsky grew up on Kossar’s bialys and Zabar’s hand-sliced Nova, developing a deep appreciation for the flavors and traditions of Jewish cuisine from an early age. His passion for food led him into the kitchens of some of the city’s most celebrated restaurants, including Eleven Madison Park, Café Sabarsky, and Wallse. With a sharp culinary mind, a love for his Eastern European and Jewish roots, and an unwavering commitment to quality, Peter set out to create something uniquely his own. That vision became Shelsky’s of Brooklyn and Shelsky’s Brooklyn Bagels—a modern take on the classic appetizing and delicatessen experience, where tradition is honored, but innovation thrives. Through his expertise, dedication, and deep respect for the craft, Peter has built a destination for smoked fish, bagels, and Jewish comfort food that stands out as a true New York institution.’ TopJaw recommends ordering the bagels.

posts.name: Sunny's Bar
posts.note: Knickknack-adorned Red Hook saloon that's been around in one guise or another since the 1890s. From their website, ‘Sunny’s Bar is known as an artists’ hangout, has been at risk of being auctioned off, but the Times reports that just last week, proprietor Sunny Balzano’s widow, Tone Balzano Johansen, gained the right to buy the building.’ From the From a Brooklyn Basement website, ‘From the outside, Sunny’s Bar is the very picture of unassuming. A lonely building, identified with a yellow “BAR” sign, on a dark cobble-stone street at the very tip of Red Hook, a Brooklyn neighborhood cut off from the rest of the borough by the roar of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and the lack of any subway stations. Standing on the sidewalk in front of the bar, you can smell the salt in the air, hear the water of New York harbor lapping against the shore.’

posts.name: Super Burrito
posts.note: From their website, ‘Super Burrito was founded by two good friends from San Francisco who wanted to bring the best version of the mission-style burrito to New York City. Skillfully rolled inside a steamed, doughy 13” tortilla are rice, beans, jack cheese, freshly made pico de gallo, house-made salsas, sliced avocado, sour cream, and flavorful grilled meats or roasted poblano chiles. A taste of home for those from the west and a new refreshing taste for those in the east, Super Burrito aims to please all.’ From the New York City Eater website, ‘After operating Super Burrito as a seasonal stand on the Rockaway Beach boardwalk for three years, owners Eugene Cleghorn and Sam Neely relocated to this permanent restaurant a few months into the pandemic, where its burritos are served year-round. Cleghorn and Neely grew up in San Francisco, and their menu pays homage to the northern California city with burritos filled with garlic shrimp, chile colorado, and other ingredients. Order the California burrito with french fries, a dish that technically calls Southern California its home but is more than done justice here.’ Here Be Barr recommends ordering the breakfast burrito. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: SYKO
posts.note: From their website, 'SYKO is part Syrian and part Korean and hopes to bring a taste of each cuisine and culture to Park Slope, Brooklyn, and the greater New York City area.' From the New York City Eater website, 'When Syko opened in 2022, it became one of the only — if not the only — Syrian Korean restaurants in the city. The menu was a byproduct of merging families, with dishes like bulgogi and shawarma served side by side. Martinez and Mu recommend ordering the SYKO Shawarma pizza.

posts.name: Taku Sando
posts.note: From their website, ‘Taku Sando brings you the best of Japan’s unique sandwich culture, aka “sando,” with a modern twist. Starting with our original shokupan milk bread, baked in-house every day, our menu takes iconic sandos like pork katsu sando and tamago sando to new heights, with careful craftsmanship and fresh quality ingredients. Enjoy a unique dining experience at our bar or spacious backyard, along with a natural wine selection designed to complement the deep flavors of the ferments we use to pack a satisfying punch. And don’t forget to come back for lunch or take some sandos out for a picnic! Freshly baked in-house every day, our original shokupan is the star of the show at Taku Sando. Shokupan, which literally means “staple food bread,” is a Japanese-style milk bread known for its beautifully fluffy texture and simple, slightly sweet flavor. Although the simplicity of the shokupan may make it seem secondary to the other components, from a Japanese perspective, it represents a wholesome luxury and is the heart of the meal. This is why we have stayed true to a familiar obsession with this bread in creating our very own shokupan, using only quality local ingredients and zero additives.’ Martinez and Mu recommend ordering the Ton-Katsu Sando, which consists of pork panko katsu, homemade shokupan, karashi mustard mayo, shredded cabbage, and house sauce.

posts.name: Tanoreen
posts.note: Tanoreen serves generous portions of Mediterranean-Middle Eastern cuisine come with a warm vibe. From their website, 'Following years of frequent dinner parties and teaching friends how to cook, chef Rawia decided to open a restaurant to share a simple idea: Cooking delicious Palestinian and Middle Eastern food as she does for family and friends, but with her unique twists. Jumana (the Daughter) always says that when you eat at Tanoreen, it’s as if you are eating at our home. We intend to highlight just that with the cuisine at Tanoreen: Home-style food meant for sharing. By that token, Tanoreen has varied in its fusions but never deviated from its roots, a blend of classical Palestinian and Middle Eastern cooking with delicious multicultural aromas stirred through. The cuisine celebrates tradition and embraces change.'

posts.name: Ursula Brooklyn
posts.note: From the New York City Eater website, ‘Ursula started in Crown Heights as a takeout operation, where it received accolades and inspired lines for its stellar breakfast burrito. In 2023, owner Eric See moved the restaurant to a bigger location in Bed-Stuy that has sit-down seating, cocktails, brunch, and dinner. Ursula isn’t just a breakfast burrito spot. It’s a “green chile-fueled love letter to New Mexico,” as Eater called it shortly after opening, ripe with stuffed sopaipillas and chile rellenos from chef-owner Eric See. Still, New Yorkers continue to line up here in the early mornings when the restaurant serves New Mexican-style burritos made with eggs, hash browns, Hatch chiles, and — best of all — smoky chorizo or vegan pinto beans. Served until noon. Breakfast burritos are the draw at this Sterling Street takeout counter, which also sells stuffed sopapillas, green chile cheeseburgers, and other New Mexican fare. Come before noon, when burritos are sold, and prepare for a wait that’s well worth it, especially if you order the version made with chorizo. The flour tortilla-wrapped creations come stuffed with scrambled eggs, hash browns, cheese, and smoky red or green chiles that owner Eric See imports from New Mexico.’ Andrew Rae (Babish) recommends ordering the carne advoda (slow-cooked pork) breakfast burrito.

posts.name: Vinegar Hill House
posts.note: Vinegar Hill House serves seasonal New American cooking served in a cozy, salvaged-decor setting with a garden. From their website, 'Vinegar Hill House is a relaxed restaurant in an unassuming and historical part of the Brooklyn waterfront. Our intent is to use the best ingredients possible through developing relationships with like-minded produce, meat, and fish producers, to compose artful and satisfying eats out of our wood-fired oven. When the weather is nice, we welcome guests for brunch or dinner in our quiet garden, under a cherry tree.' from the New York City Etaer website, 'Long beloved in the micro neighborhood-within-a-neighborhood it’s named after; Vinegar Hill House serves simply prepared and thoughtfully sourced New American fare, like a crisp, moist cast iron chicken with shallots and sherry vinegar jus. The cozy, woody space helps make it the kind of restaurant to return to several times a week. The same team opened VHH Foods, a daytime cafe with pastries, sandwiches, and other takeout-friendly bites, now located within the West Elm store on Main Street.'

posts.name: Yemen Cafe and Restaurant
posts.note: From their website, ‘Our menu features a wide array of great selections served in generous portions. It’s a true reflection of Yemen’s rich culinary traditions. From the moment you sit down, you’ll experience the heart of Yemeni cuisine in every bite. Each dish is made with fresh ingredients and traditional recipes passed down through generations. Despite the expectation of red meat bliss -- chops and fresh fish are also on the menu for anyone who thinks he or she has been steered in the wrong direction. Step into the heart of authentic Yemeni cuisine at Yemen Cafe and Restaurant, where every dish tells a story of tradition and rich flavors. Experience the warm hospitality and savor expertly prepared specialties, from fragrant rice dishes to tender, slow-cooked meats. Whether you’re here for a family gathering or a quick meal, you’ll find an inviting atmosphere and unforgettable tastes inspired by Yemen’s culinary heritage. Indulge in our signature Fahsah, a delightful combination of traditional Saltah and tender shredded lamb, served bubbling hot in a clay bowl. Paired with freshly baked clay oven bread, hearty soup, and a crisp house salad, this dish offers an authentic taste of Yemen.’ Martinez and Mu recommend ordering the Chicken Haneeth, a slow oven-roasted chicken (half) in imported Yemeni seasoning served over a bed of long-grain basmati rice and topped with a vegetable sauce. I would likely order a lamb dish. NOTE: They have multiple locations.
